dataset.title: Effects of land cover, topography, and built structure on seasonal water quality at multiple spatial scales in Clark County, WA and the metropolitan area of Portland, OR
dataset.abstract: <section><para>The relationship among land cover, topography, built structure and stream water quality in the Portland Metro region of Oregon and Clark County, Washington areas, USA, is analyzed using ordinary least squares (OLS) and geographically weighted (GWR) multiple regression models. Two scales of analysis, a sectional watershed and a buffer, offered a local and a global investigation of the sources of stream pollutants. Model accuracy, measured by R2 values, fluctuated according to the scale, season, and regression method used. While most wet season water quality parameters are associated with urban land covers, most dry season water quality parameters are related topographic features such as elevation and slope. GWR models, which take into consideration local relations of spatial autocorrelation, had stronger results than OLS regression models. In the multiple regression models, sectioned watershed results were consistently better than the sectioned buffer results, except for dry season pH and stream temperature parameters. This suggests that while riparian land cover does have an effect on water chemistry and quality, a wider contributing area needs to be included in order to account for distant sources of pollutants.</para></section>
dataset.additionalInfo: <section><para>B. Pratt, H. Chang. Effects of land cover, topography, and built structure on seasonal water quality at multiple spatial scales, J. Hazard. Mater. 209– 210 (2012) 48– 58. Collected from Portland Bureau of Environmental Services and Clark County Environmental Services’ long-term monitoring program. </para></section>
dataset.intellectualRights: <section><title>Data Use Agreement</title><para> Any Forest science data Bank (FSDB) data set and accompanying metadata available on these web pages can be downloaded for academic, research, recreational, and other professional purposes. Permission to download data sets is granted to the Data User without a fee subject to the following terms. The Data User will: </para><para><itemizedlist><listitem><para> notify the designated contact (e.g., Principle Investigator or Data Set Contact) when any derivative work based on or derived from the data and documentation is distributed; </para></listitem><listitem><para> notify users that such derivative work is a modified version and not the original data and documentation distributed by the FSDB;</para></listitem><listitem><para> not redistribute original data and documentation; </para></listitem><listitem><para> acknowledge the support of the Forest Science data Bank in any publications using these data and documentation. (See general acknowledgement below and see web page for specific data citation for each study data set); </para></listitem><listitem><para> send two reprints of any publications resulting from use of the data and documentation to the following address: Andrews Experimental Forest LTER Program, c/o Don Henshaw, Forestry Sciences Lab, 3200 SW Jefferson Way, Corvallis, OR 97331</para></listitem></itemizedlist><para> By using or copying these data and documentation, the Data User agrees to abide by the terms of this agreement. The Forest Science Data Bank shall have the right to terminate this agreement immediately by written notice upon the Data User’s breach of, or non-compliance with, any of its terms. The Data User may be held responsible for any misuse that is caused or encouraged by the Data User’s failure to abide by the terms of this agreement. Thank you for your cooperation. We hope your collaboration with our site is a productive one!</para><para> Disclaimer: While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. All data are made available "AS IS". The Forest Science Data Bank shall not be liable for damages resulting from any use or misinterpretation of data sets.</para><para> General acknowledgement: Data sets were provided by the Forest Science Data Bank, a partnership between the Department of Forest Science, Oregon State University, and the U.S. Forest Service Pacific Northwest Research Station, Corvallis, Oregon. </para></section>
dataset.purpose: <section><para>This study was developed as part of the interdisciplinary PV-ULTRA-Ex project to investigate the complex interactions and feedback among land development, disturbance and water quality in the Portland/Vancouver metropolitan area. This particular study explores the relationship between landscape variables and water quality in the Portland, Oregon and Clark County, Washington area to examine if the season or scale of analysis matters in determining what land cover has the most influence on water quality.The study additionally compares the predictive power of GWR, which incorporates spatial autocorrelation, to a global OLS regression model.</para></section>

section.para: An update history is logged and maintained with each new version of every dataset.

changeHistory.changeScope: Study code and preliminary metadata established
Uploaded entity and attribute metadata through move_xls and uploaded data using editdb.

address.deliveryPoint: US Forest Service Pacific Northwest Research Station
Forest Ecosystems and Society Department in Forestry

studyExtent.description: <section><para>Balch Creek, Columbia Slough, Fanno Creek, Johnson Creek, Kelley Creeks, Tryon Creeks, Westside Streams, Willamette River</para></section>

dataTable.entityDescription: Monthly stream water chemistry data collected by the Portland Bureau of Environmental Services: Water chemistry parameters in Portland Metro area

Construction near site
Construction has ended near site
Cu and Zn detected in rinsate sample may be due to contamination of water used to prepare the rinsate
This site is dammed more than last time. Washington County has been notified.
Debris dam downstream has creek backed up at mouth of culverts.
Large debris build up immediately downstream
Collected from N Denver bridge
Depth = 1.0 ft.
Depth = 10 ft.
Depth = 4.5 ft.

DO Membrane damaged.
Dissolved oxygen > 200% saturation
Active dredging near site
Dye testing was in progress at WWTP outfall
Bank erosion
Water surface frozen

Iron deposits leaching into pool at sample point

Leaves in pool at site
Sample collected from the North Lombard/Marine Drive bridge
Due to summer low flow conditions, sample was collected approximately 3 ft. downstream from transect
Creek has odor similar to raw sewage
Oily sheen on water surface
Oil-like sheen on water's surface at all sites, especially US-21
Oak Creek WTP outfall was discharging
PAH: Low recoveries for lightest congener surrogates indicate results for Cl1 - Cl4 congeners could be low estimates
Hard rain begins at 12:30
Rip-rap has been added to the bank immediately downstream of sample site
Pacific Giant Salamander at sampling location
Slow flow
Sewage spill warning sign in place; spill occurred approximately 1 week ago
At site, creek is stagnant and filled with floating leaves
Water very turbid
Water very turbid due to recent rains
Flow appeared to be moving upstream
Sample collected from N Vancouver bridge
Missed bacteria sample

attribute.attributeDefinition: Notes from lab processing of samples

codeDefinition.definition: The result for dissolved arsenic slightly greater than total arsenic is statistically insignificant (< 20% RPD)

The result for dissolved arsenic slightly greater than total arsenic is statistically insignificant (< 20% RPD). The result for dissolved molybdenum is slightly greater than total molybdenum. Because the difference is st
The result for BOD is not reportable because of failed QC (blank > 0.2 depletion). However, the results indicate that the BOD is < 10 mg/l.
BOD: the RPD for duplicate analysis exceeds the control limit, but is not applicable because the results are less than 5 times the MRL.
The presence of a small green leaf was noted in the sample bottle provided for chlorophyll-a analysis. This probably explains the presence of chlorophyll-a in the rinsate sample.
The sample returned a result of 4.7 mg/l chloride. This is the only value of any kind for chloride testing in this data set. Method: EPA 300.0
The result for dissolved chromium is slightly greater than total chromium. Because the difference is statistically insignificant (< 20% RPD), the sample was not re-analyzed.
The result for dissolved copper is slightly greater than total copper. Because the difference is statistically insignificant (< 20% RPD), the sample was not re-analyzed.

The result for dissolved copper is slightly greater than total copper. Because the difference is statistically insignificant (< 20% RPD), the sample was not re-analyzed. The result for dissolved lead is slightly greater

The sample tested positive for Enterococcus from a bird source and negative for Enterococcus from a human source. Refer to contract laboratory report for detailed information on the analysis for sources of Bacteroidetes
The final reading for fecal coliform bacteria was done 11 minutes past the incubation period of 24 +/- 2 hrs. The result was probably not affected, but could be biased slightly high.
RAD: Lab filtering blank
Analysis for magnesium and calcium to calculate hardness was performed by EPA method 200.8.
Manganese was analyzed by EPA method 200.7, ICP-AES.
The result for dissolved manganese is slightly greater than total manganese. Because the difference is statistically insignificant (< 20% RPD), the sample was not re-analyzed.
The result for dissolved molybdenum is slightly greater than total molybdenum. Because the difference is statistically insignificant (< 20% RPD), the sample was not re-analyzed.
Since the result for total oil and grease is <5 mg/l, non-polar oil and grease is also < 5 mg/l.

Since the result for total oil and grease is <5 mg/l, non-polar oil and grease is also < 5 mg/l.The results for pesticides that were detected at a level less than the reporting limit are reported as estimates.
This sample was filtered for ortho-phosphate the day after collection.
Analysis for PAH compounds detected phenathrene at a concentration just below the reporting limit of 0.10 ug/l.
The result for dissolved lead is slightly greater than for total lead. Because the difference is statistically insignificant (< 20% RPD), the sample was not re-analyzed.
The results for pesticides that were detected at a level less than the reporting limit are reported as estimates.

An additional parameter analysis was completed for this sample, but the parameter analyzed is unknown. The type of analysis conducted was recorded as "refer to contract report" with a measured value of 10 ng/l. Method: E

TSS result is an average of 3 replicates; sample matrix was difficult to keep in suspension for analysis due to sandy particulate.
TSS: sample was filtered and dried but was not re-weighed.
TSS RPD is not relevant because one of the sample results was less than 5
TSS: duplicate RPD result is not applicable because sample results are less than 5 times the MRL.
The result for dissolved zinc is slightly greater than total zinc. Because the difference is statistically insignificant (< 20% RPD), the sample was not re-analyzed.

Standard Methods for determining membrane filtration test for fecal coliforms (www.nemi.gov)
Standard Methods for determining membrane filtration plating of E. coli with MUG-fluorescent detection (www.nemi.gov)
Standard Methods for determining enzyme substrate assay for measuring total coliforms and E. coli (ONPG-MUG test or CPRG-MUG test) (www.nemi.gov)

Average of two depth readings of sighting of Secchi disk in the water: depth when disk disappears from sight when lowered from surface and depth of reappearance when disk is raised from lower depths (BES Field SOPs)
Water Pollution Control Laboratory method, Standard Operating Procedure M-1 (http://www.portlandonline.com/bes/index.cfm?c=57758&a=221340)
Water Pollution Control Laboratory method, Standard Operating Procedure M-10 (http://www.portlandonline.com/bes/index.cfm?c=57758&a=221340)

date method ceased at a site
